text: PROFESSOR: OK so today we're doing
antiderivatives and other uses of the indefinite integrals.
Next week we'll be doing the review before the final exam,
and so next we'll go over a bunch of problems
that I've prepared, but also any questions that you have.
So if you have questions while you're preparing for the exam
by doing all the practice exams, you can send an email,
let me know.
Or you could just bring them to class and we'll do them then.
If you have specific topics that you want to cover,
try to send me an email before class
so that I make sure to I prepare a problem for that,
or bring-- I can bring one of the practice exam
problems or whatever.
So just let me know what you need,
and we'll do review next week, and we'll hopefully
have a good final exam.
But before that, we'll do antiderivatives
and indefinite integrals.
And so what is an indefinite integral?
What does it look like?
STUDENT: There's no limits.
PROFESSOR: So there's no bounds.
So if we have like x cubed plus 4x, dx,
what would the answer to this be?
STUDENT: X cubed-- x to the 4 over 4.
plus 2x squared plus c.
PROFESSOR: Plus C. OK, and we talked about this last time.
What is this?
Why is this here?
Why is this plus c here?
STUDENT: Because you can have infinite number of--
PROFESSOR: Yeah.
There's an infinite number of these equations
that the derivative of it is x cubed plus 4 x.
OK so we'll do some sketching.
So on this side we'll have little f,
which is going to be equal to big f prime.
And on this side we'll have big F. OK
so I'm going to draw little f which
is the derivative of big F. So if I make the chart
that we normally have when we're sketching,
so we'll have positive, negative, increasing,
decreasing, concave up, concave down.
What goes down here?
Just to quickly refresh.
STUDENT: XX.
PROFESSOR: XX So we know nothing about positive negative,
plus minus, increasing decreasing.
OK so now based on what I've put up here we have big F
and little f.
Which one goes where?
Little f at the bottom, because little f
is the derivative of big F. So I recommend always
writing this on your paper on the exams.
Always writing this chart on your paper
and always using the exact notations
that he's used on these graphs, so that you
know when I give you one of them and you
need to do the other, which part of it is doing what.
You'll also see on the exam sometimes, he'll
give you the middle one and you'll
have to do both the antiderivative
and the derivative, does that make sense?
So you'll need to maybe do this chart one line further.
But I recommend doing that.
OK so our first one will be pretty simple.
OK so which part are we looking at
to try to figure out what this will--
what the antiderivative will look like?
Which section of this matters?
OK so this is positive.
OK and is it increasing or decreasing or neither?
Neither, OK.
So up here, what do we think this one's going to look like?
STUDENT: Increasing.
PROFESSOR: It's going to be an increasing line.
Does it matter where it is?
It should be positive?
So it could be positive or negative?
Can it go through?
Sorry?
STUDENT: Slope has to be positive.
PROFESSOR: Slope has to be positive.
OK.
So if I draw this line, does that work?
OK.
Because the slope is constantly positive.
And it's a constant.
It's a constant slope.
I didn't draw a curve.
I drew a line with a constant slope,
and this is what you would do.
This is-- if I took the derivative of this,
I drew the derivative, I would get this line.
OK.
What's another line that would look like this?
Another antiderivative.
STUDENT: Shift it up or down.
PROFESSOR: So we could have all of these, right?
All of those work.
Infinitely many, up and down the graph.
Great.
Any questions about that?
OK.
So we'll do another one.
These are supposed to get increasingly difficult.
OK so this time we have this line that
crosses the x-axis there.
So I'm going to put a little dash there to know that maybe
something happens or maybe it doesn't.
OK so from this point to this point, what can you
tell me about this function?
STUDENT: It's constant.
PROFESSOR: It's constant.
The slope of this constant.
Does that matter?
No.
Because I'm not taking the derivative of this.
The slope of this doesn't matter.
It's positive.
And what else?
Decreasing.
OK so positive and decreasing means that from this point
here to this point, what's going to happen
to this graph, the antiderivative?
STUDENT: Increasing concave down.
PROFESSOR: Increasing.
So we got positive increasing, and then we
had decreasing concave down.
OK, so what will it look like?
STUDENT: So it would be like [INAUDIBLE] half,
half [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: So that the slope is what at this point?
STUDENT: Should be 0.
PROFESSOR: Yeah, the slope should be 0 at this point,
right?
Because over here, the slope-- this value is 0.
So if I take the derivative of this, this curve, and the value
is 0 here, we'll have the peak of our parabola,
or of our curve.
OK?
And so then what happens from this point to the end?
STUDENT: It's negative.
STUDENT: Decreasing, concave down.
PROFESSOR: Negative, decreasing.
So our antiderivative is what?
Decreasing and concave down?
STUDENT: Yep.
PROFESSOR: OK, so there was no inflection point, right?
It stayed concave down the whole time.
OK.
Does everyone agree?
All right, so what would another one look like?
STUDENT: Shift it up or down.
PROFESSOR: Shift it up or down.
That was actually pretty close, but the 0
is supposed to be there.
It'd be here, OK?
Questions on that?
OK, these are pretty easy?
OK.
So these probably are pretty easy because we did them
the other way so many times.
We took the original and made the derivative so many times.
But that also means that when you're on the exam,
you really need to be careful about whether it's
asking for the derivative or for the antiderivative,
because if you're not reading carefully
you might do the wrong one.
Let's do this one.
So from here to here, what's happening?
STUDENT: It's positive going down.
PROFESSOR: OK, so this is like the last one.
And what happens at this point on our antiderivative?
STUDENT: The tangent is 0.
PROFESSOR: The tangent is 0.
OK, so where should I start on here
and what should it look like?
It's going to be increasing and concave down.
STUDENT: Concave down.
PROFESSOR: OK, so--
STUDENT: Same as before.
PROFESSOR: Same as before?
So maybe we'll go like that?
That look right?
So this tangent is 0.
On this side what do we have?
We now have positive and increasing,
so the only difference is what?
STUDENT: Concave up.
PROFESSOR: Concave up, so it'll look like that.
OK, so is this continuous or not continuous?
STUDENT: Continuous.
PROFESSOR: It's continuous.
If I took the derivative of this,
would it be continuous or not continuous?
STUDENT: Not continuous.
PROFESSOR: Not continuous, because what
happens at this point?
STUDENT: It would be infinite number of tangents.
PROFESSOR: Yeah, I could draw a million tangents to this,
or infinite tangents to this.
So the derivative of this is not continuous, but as you see,
the antiderivative was continuous.
So it's important to know.
And then of course, as we said before, all of these
will be possible antiderivatives.
OK, one last one and then we'll move on.
Nobody has any questions about these?
OK.
That's really good.
OK, so let's do-- OK, so this is a continuous-- this is a line
segment with one slope, and this is a line segment
with another slope.
So what do we need to know?
From here to what point would matter?
STUDENT: On the x, where it crosses it.
PROFESSOR: Here?
STUDENT: Yeah.
PROFESSOR: OK, so how would you describe this section?
STUDENT: Positive and increasing-- sorry, negative.
PROFESSOR: Negative and increasing, yep.
So until this section on our function here,
what would it look like?
It would be decreasing and?
STUDENT: Concave up.
PROFESSOR: Concave up?
OK.
So where are we?
We're here, and at this point what's special?
STUDENT: The slope is 0.
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm.
So that's what it should look like, right, where the slope
is 0?
OK, from here to here, what's happening?
STUDENT: Positive, increasing.
PROFESSOR: Positive, increasing.
So from here to here, we have what?
Increasing--
STUDENT: Concave up.
PROFESSOR: Concave up.
So this is one like a parabola, right there.
And then what happens from here to here?
STUDENT: It's positive and increasing.
PROFESSOR: So it's the same, but what's different about it?
STUDENT: It's more dramatic.
PROFESSOR: It's more dramatic, so the slope is?
STUDENT: Greater.
PROFESSOR: Greater.
OK, so if I'm going to draw this,
this side goes like this, right?
So if it was the same parabola, it would go like this, yes?
This was one continuous line that went out this way.
So what should it look like instead,
more like inside or outside?
STUDENT: Inside.
PROFESSOR: Like that.
OK?
Maybe not quite so bendy, but a nice curve that goes up.
But there's a distinction between this curve
and that curve.
Questions about these things?
STUDENT: What are the major differences
if you were going to be asked to plot either the derivative
or antiderivative?
So for instance, one of them, when
you see the-- like the absolute value graph,
I know for antiderivative it's going to be continuous
but for derivative it wouldn't be.
Are there other ones that--
PROFESSOR: Those are the main ones, where
the points of continuity are asymptotes,
where if you're taking the antiderivative,
you might be able to find it, or if you're
taking the derivative, you won't be able to find it,
or vice-versa.
But yeah, I think those are the main points.
Because here we were able to do the same thing, right?
Here there's another point of discontinuity
if you're taking the derivative.
But you create a pretty interesting antiderivative
from it.
So I think you'll find the same things.
Of course, you'll see, as you've seen on previous tests,
his will be a lot longer and they'll
have lots of ups and downs for you to figure out.
And taking the antiderivative and the derivative
will be interesting at each of those points.
Yeah.
OK, so let's do a couple of word things.
OK, so we have a population that is changing at a rate of f of t
equals t minus 3 in thousands of people per year.
So does this give you the population
if I solve this equation?
No, it gives me the rate, yes?
At t equals 0-- or at t0, the population is 30.
So this is really f of 0, yes?
At t equals 0.
The population is 30, and that's of course in thousand people.
OK, so our first question is, when is the population lowest?
How might we go about finding this, or what's another way
to word this question?
STUDENT: Where you use a number line
to find the current points.
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm.
So we're looking for-- say it again?
STUDENT: Global min.
PROFESSOR: The global min.
OK.
So how do we do this, how do we solve this?
STUDENT: t is equal to 3?
One of the critical points.
PROFESSOR: We need to find the critical points, yes.
But f of t is equal to what?
Not just this.
Like logistically, what is f of t equal to?
f of t is the rate of change of the population.
STUDENT: Derivative.
PROFESSOR: It's the derivative of the population, yes?
OK.
And so this is equal to t minus 3.
So when we were looking at populations and rates of change
of things before, when we didn't know integrals,
when we were seeking the global min of an equation,
what did we do?
We took the derivative and then we set it equal to 0.
So now that we have the derivative already-- because we
want the global min of the population, not the global min
of the rate, right?
We don't want to take the derivative of this
again, because then we would be looking at the min of the rate,
and we're going to look at the min of the population.
So we set this to 0, yes?
So when is it 0?
STUDENT: t is equal to 3.
PROFESSOR: Right.
OK, and so now what do we do?
STUDENT: Number line?
PROFESSOR: Yeah, so we're going to test this on a number line
to see if 3 is the min or the max.
Which functions go on either side of this?
STUDENT: P prime at the bottom.
PROFESSOR: P prime at the bottom and P at the top,
so this is equal to f, yes?
OK, so what number should we test?
STUDENT: 0.
PROFESSOR: Sure, we can test 0.
Which do we plug into, f or P?
STUDENT: F prime.
PROFESSOR: f prime?
STUDENT: Sorry, P prime.
PROFESSOR: Yes, P prime.
So f, so f of-- you wanted to do 0?
Is what?
0 minus 3, so that's negative.
So what's happening to P?
STUDENT: Going down.
PROFESSOR: Going down.
And then what's on this side?
STUDENT: 4.
PROFESSOR: 4, or any other number that's higher than 3.
So 4 minus 3 is positive, so this is--
STUDENT: Going up.
PROFESSOR: OK, so the population is decreasing until 3
and increasing after 3, so what do we know from this?
STUDENT: 3 is the min?
PROFESSOR: t equals 3 is the min.
The population is lowest at time 3.
And time 3 is what in words?
It's three years in to this problem.
OK, so what is the maximum population
between year 0 and year 10?
What are the possibilities that we want to look at for this?
STUDENT: We want to definitely look at 0 and at 10.
PROFESSOR: We want to look at 0 and 10.
Is there anywhere else we want to look?
STUDENT: Probably not.
You know t of 3 is the minimum.
PROFESSOR: We know that t of 3 is
the minimum, so if we were trying to sketch this out
and we have t 3, and--
STUDENT: Upward concave up parabola.
PROFESSOR: You think it would look like this?
Let's assume that starts at 0.
So we need to know if 0-- if 10 is up here
or if 10 is down here, what's going on, right?
That graph is not to scale.
I didn't do that based on anything.
This is just like what your mind should be thinking about.
So our ideas are maybe t equals 0, maybe t equals 10.
OK, how do we solve this?
What are we going to need to do?
STUDENT: Take the antiderivative.
PROFESSOR: Yeah, we're going to take
the antiderivative of our rate to find what our population is.
We want to know what the actual value of the population
is at each of these.
So if we take the derivative of f of t,
we should get P t, right?
I'm sorry, if we take the integral of f of t,
we'll get P t.
So the integral of t minus 3 dt is what?
STUDENT: t squared over 2 minus 3t.
PROFESSOR: Minus 3t.
STUDENT: Plus c.
PROFESSOR: Plus c.
OK, but this isn't super helpful, right?
Because if I plug in 0, I'll get 0 minus 0
plus c, so I know that's c.
And at 10-- I mean, I guess I could.
This is actually helpful.
But I want to know what c actually is.
How do we do that?
STUDENT: You know from the equation at time t equals 0--
PROFESSOR: The population is 30.
STUDENT: --the population is 30.
PROFESSOR: So now we know p 0 equals
30, which means that if we plug in for 0, we have 1/2 of 0
squared minus 3 times 0 plus c equals 30.
So now c equals?
STUDENT: 30.
PROFESSOR: 30.
OK, so our P t is 1/2 t squared minus 3t plus 30.
OK, so what's our next step?
STUDENT: Now you can plug in t equals 10.
PROFESSOR: OK, t equals 10.
So we know that p of 0 is 30, so now we just need to test 10.
So P of 10 will be 1/2 times 10 squared
minus 3 times 10 plus 30.
So what is that equal to?
STUDENT: 50.
PROFESSOR: 50.
OK, so which one's the maximum population?
So we have our max population--
STUDENT: 10 years.
PROFESSOR: --at 10 years.
OK, so as you saw from this graph earlier
that we started to draw, if the lowest point of our parabola
is at 3, the symmetrical point will be at what?
The symmetrical point to t 0--
STUDENT: 6.
PROFESSOR: --will be at 6.
And then it will increase to 10.
So we could have known from this problem
without doing any of this math, we
could've known from the shape of a parabola, which
is going to be the antiderivative of our rate,
we could have known that 10 would be the highest.
However, this math really proves it.
This math really proves that 50 is higher than 30, which
means that 10 years is the max.
OK, any questions on that?
No?
OK.
So our next question is, what is the average rate of change
over the interval 0 to 10?
How do we compute the average rate of change?
STUDENT: In general, or for this?
PROFESSOR: Both.
Either.
STUDENT: P 10 minus P 0 divided by 10 minus 0.
PROFESSOR: P 10 minus P 0 over 10 minus 0?
Yes.
So what's the other way to describe this?
STUDENT: y [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: Change in y over change in x?
For the rate of change, right?
So we didn't have to do anything.
We didn't have to do any antiderivatives,
we didn't have to do any derivatives.
We can just calculate it.
OK, so we know P 10 is what?
STUDENT: 50.
PROFESSOR: 50.
P 0 was?
STUDENT: 30.
PROFESSOR: 30.
And then 10 minus 0 is 10.
So what is this?
STUDENT: 2.
PROFESSOR: 2 what?
Thousand people per year.
OK, it's important to include those units so you
know what you're talking about.
OK, so if that's the average rate
of change, what's the average population
over the same interval, 0 to 10?
How do we calculate this?
STUDENT: The integral of P.
PROFESSOR: The integral of P.
STUDENT: Over 0 to 10 times 1 over 10 minus 0.
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm, perfect.
STUDENT: Where did the 1/10 come from?
PROFESSOR: You're doing kind of the same thing
as you doing you're doing up here,
in that you're dividing by the length of the interval.
STUDENT: OK.
PROFESSOR: So you're doing the integral
over the length of the interval.
STUDENT: Oh, I see.
PROFESSOR: Yeah.
OK, so what will this look like?
What's the integral of P t dt?
STUDENT: You should take the integral of P t?
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm.
STUDENT: So that's t cubed over 6.
1/2 t squared.
PROFESSOR: No, sorry.
We'll want to do the integral of the rate.
We want to do the integral of P prime of t.
STUDENT: Rate?
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm.
Because then we'll get the population.
Sorry, I should've included the prime.
So we already know this integral.
STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE] t squared.
PROFESSOR: Yeah.
STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: Oh, no.
STUDENT: She had it right.
PROFESSOR: No, I had it right, I had it right, I had it right.
I had it right, sorry.
0 to 10 of 1/2 t squared minus 3t plus 30 dt.
Sometimes my notes are very unclear.
OK, so now we're going to do this, and Vishal,
you had this right, so why don't you do it?
STUDENT: t cubed over--
PROFESSOR: t cubed over 6.
STUDENT: Minus 3/2 t squared.
PROFESSOR: Yep.
STUDENT: And 30t plus c.
PROFESSOR: Plus c?
STUDENT: Oh, I'm sorry, no.
You need limits.
PROFESSOR: From 0 to 10.
OK?
So now we have this 1/10 times-- and now we're
going to plug 10 in.
So 1/6 times 10 cubed minus 3/2 times 10 squared plus 30 times
STUDENT: Minus 0.
PROFESSOR: Minus 0.
STUDENT: I'll do that part.
PROFESSOR: It's good, we need everyone to contribute.
So we have 1/10 times?
STUDENT: 1,000 over 6.
PROFESSOR: 1,000 over 6, minus?
STUDENT: 300.
STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: 300 over 2 plus 300, Yes?
Am I right?
OK.
I have the eraser in my other hand.
OK, so we need to just combine some fractions here.
So we have 1/10 times-- which denominator do you
guys want to use, or how do you want to simplify them?
STUDENT: Just multiply through by 10 first [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: You want to multiply, you want
to multiply this through first?
STUDENT: Yeah.
PROFESSOR: Sure.
STUDENT: So you have 100 over 6 and then--
PROFESSOR: So we have 100 over 6 minus 30 over 2 plus 30?
30, yes?
OK, so now--
STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE] 100 over 6 minus 15 plus 30, or you
can just say plus 15 there.
PROFESSOR: Minus 15.
Oh, minus 15 plus 30.
STUDENT: Yeah.
PROFESSOR: OK.
You can even leave this as this if you wanted.
It's not wrong.
But you can simplify even more, but you don't need to.
I think the answer is 31 and 2/3.
31 and 2/3 what?
STUDENT: [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: 1,000 people.
OK.
STUDENT: So can I ask you a question? [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: Sure.
STUDENT: I got a little bit confused.
You already took a derivative-- sorry,
you took an integral of a derivative already,
and then you're taking another integral of the integral
you've already taken.
PROFESSOR: Yes.
STUDENT: So we're basically taking integral twice.
PROFESSOR: Integral twice.
STUDENT: So why do you need to take it for a second time?
Why can't you just take the original equation,
plug the numbers in, get an average.
PROFESSOR: You can do that.
That is a way to do that.
If you wanted to do average population and do-- oh no,
you-- so when we took the average rate of change,
we took the population, right?
We took the integral, basically, of this rate of change
to get the population and we did the rate.
STUDENT: Right, so I'm looking at that.
PROFESSOR: Yes.
STUDENT: So we took the integral of the rate of change.
So we got P t is equal to 1/2 t squared minus 3t plus 30.
PROFESSOR: Yes, and that's equal to the population.
STUDENT: So to me, that gives you the original function,
basically.
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm, that is the original function, yeah.
STUDENT: And then you're taking that and integrating it again.
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm, so that we can get the average of that
over itself.
STUDENT: So why couldn't you just get the average from that?
STUDENT: Because you'd get 40.
30 plus 50 is 80, divided by 2 would be 40,
so you don't get the right answer.
PROFESSOR: Yeah, you would be adding the ends
and then dividing, and that wouldn't be quite right.
You want to add basically all of them up along that whole thing
and divide by the whole interval.
And so that's what you're doing when you take the integral,
is you're adding everything up and then
dividing to find what the average value is.
STUDENT: Like the [INAUDIBLE] on something.
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm, exactly.
OK, any other questions?
All right, this is going a lot faster than I thought.
STUDENT: If you didn't have a parabolic shape in the equation
when you do part B, would you have to test all of the points?
I mean, is there a function for which it wouldn't be like B?
I guess if it was negative or something.
PROFESSOR: You would want to predict the shape.
You would want to predict the shape.
You wouldn't be asked to do something
like that unless there was a way to do it, right.
So in this it would be obvious.
There might be-- if you had like a cubic function,
you would be able to do the same kind of thing.
You'd be able to figure out based on doing the increasing,
decreasing, increasing, whatever, you'd
be able to figure out where you were
in the shape of the graph you're in,
and try to predict where the endpoints are.
Yeah, it's very good to kind of sketch
out what kind of equations you're
dealing with to whatever extent you can.
That's a very good skill to have and a tool to use.
STUDENT: Yeah, I found that difficult to imagine.
It's a cubic equation.
You're getting an average population
from the cubic equation?
PROFESSOR: Mm-hm.
This one here?
STUDENT: Yeah.
PROFESSOR: Yeah, so you're taking your population,
taking in the antiderivative, and then doing it from there,
yeah.
OK, so let's do a motion one.
So we have an object and it's launched from 3 feet up
at an initial velocity of 66 meters per second.
OK.
What's gravity equal to?
STUDENT: Negative 9.8 meters per second squared.
PROFESSOR: OK, negative 9.8 meters per second squared.
So our first question is, what's the maximum height?
So what are the three things that we normally
look at when we're looking at motion, motion problems?
Like what are the three types of equations we write out?
STUDENT: Acceleration and velocity, distance.
PROFESSOR: Yeah, acceleration, velocity, position.
OK, what's the relationship between these three?
Let's say this is h of t, v of t, a of t.
STUDENT: Use the derivative of a [INAUDIBLE].
PROFESSOR: v the derivative of which one?
STUDENT: h.
PROFESSOR: h.
So where's the prime going to go, on v or on h?
STUDENT: On h.
PROFESSOR: h, OK.
And then a is the derivative of which one?
STUDENT: v.
PROFESSOR: v. OK.
And then for integrals, which one's which?
STUDENT: Take the integral of velocity and get h.
PROFESSOR: OK.
STUDENT: And integral of a or acceleration to get velocity.
PROFESSOR: OK.
So these things should help us.
Where can we start very easily with what we know?
We know the initial position, we know the initial velocity,
and we know gravity.
What should we start with?
What's the first equation we know?
STUDENT: Go with gravity.
PROFESSOR: OK, so we know that the acceleration a of t
is equal to--
STUDENT: Minus 9.8
PROFESSOR: --minus 9.8.
OK.
What can we do now?
STUDENT: Take the integral and you'll have the velocity.
PROFESSOR: So if we take the integral of this
we'll get the velocity, OK?
So what's the integral of negative 9.8 dt?
STUDENT: Negative 9.8t.
PROFESSOR: Negative 9.8t.
STUDENT: Plus c.
PROFESSOR: Plus c.
And this equals the velocity.
So can we get a better equation for velocity than negative 9.8t
plus c?
STUDENT: You can solve for c.
PROFESSOR: We can solve for c.
And how do we do that?
STUDENT: Starting from 0, or--
PROFESSOR: Close.
